choices.A: The web server is missing an intermediate certificate.
choices.C: TLS is not enabled in the browser.
choices.B: The website is missing an HTTPS certificate.

discussion.content: I would say the answer is D, purely because the message displayed states that the certificate cannot be trusted, which makes me think there is a certificate present so it can't be missing.
Thought D
Bad stated question... I would also say it could be D. In my head certificate from a trusted authority expired and they are currently using a self-signed certificate.
"The most common cause of a "certificate not trusted" error is that the certificate installation was not properly completed on the server (or servers) hosting the site."

comments.content: I don't think it's D because the site would give an error that says "The certificate has expired or is not yet valid."

discussion.content: Wording in this question isn't great but I believe the given answer is correct. Installing the Intermediate Cert is one of the first steps to fixing this issue.
Key word "CERTAIN". Some other websites are reachable. Therefore the SSL certificate cannot be expired.

The question does not state that the user is attempting to connect to web pages that require encryption, i.e. SSL/TLS (Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security); instead, we can only assume that "certain web pages" are merely regular web pages that do not entail the transmission of encrypted data. Hence, an SSL certificate is surely not required in this instance since not all websites utilise SSL/TLS. For that reason, (A) seems like the most credible answer. Anyone disagree?
i thought it was D
The answer could be D as well

questions.question_text:
Joe, a user, is having issues when trying to access certain web pages. Upon navigating to a web page, it seems like it connects, but then presents the following message:
The security certificate presented by this website was not trusted by a trusted certificate authority.
Joe has cleared his cache and cookies, rebooted his machine, and attempted to browse to the website from a coworker's desktop, but it still presented with this error.
Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of this error?

discussion.content: Keyword : duration - lease time. rest are void

questions.question_text: Which of the following is used to define the duration during which a client can use an IP address?

discussion.content: bridge is the answer here. The bridge is a network device which is used to divide a LAN into multiple segments.
Jason Dion says layer 2 devices are dummies.

b-but professor Messer says there's no such thing as a layer 3 switch!
Jokes aside this questions if worded awfully.
Either way answer is B

A network engineer wants to a segment the network into multiple broadcast domains. Which of the following devices would allow for communication between the segments?

L3 switch because L3 switch will acts as a switch to connect devices that are on the same subnet or virtual LAN into multiple broadcast domain (router).
I would say that correct answer is B, because it is neccesary to allow communication between segments. So we need L3 switch.

comments.content: I agree with you, using Layer 2 switch is good enough. It can make some VLAN to segment the network
Layer 2 switches work with VLANs, but I think they do not allow for communication from one VLAN to another VLAN.

discussion.content: I actually thought this would be a Layer 2 Switch because a Layer 3 switch is almost a router and routers dont accept broadcasts.

questions.question_text: A network engineer wants to segment the network into multiple broadcast domains. Which of the following devices would allow for communication between the segments?

choices.B: The use of autonomous APs with a wireless controller
choices.D: The use of lightweight APs with a wireless controller
choices.C: The use of autonomous APs with a load balancer
choices.A: The use of lightweight APs with a load balancer

questions.question_text:
A small company is requesting a quote to refresh its wireless network. The company currently runs 60 autonomous APs and has plans to increase wireless density by 50% in the near future. The requirements state that the chosen solution should significantly decrease the management overhead of the current wireless network.
Which of the following should the vendors recommend in response to the quote request?

comments.content: That's exactly the idea. A google search on the difference between the two brings up plenty of articles explaining exactly that.

discussion.content: So yeah, lightweight is easier to manage because it is controlled through a centralized wireless controller?

A lightweight access point is going to rely entirely upon a wireless LAN controller, where an autonomous access point is just that. Itâ€™s autonomous. While autonomous points are amazing when working alone, when they need more help, they might not be the best option.

questions.question_text: A network technician receives a trouble ticket and speaks to the user who is experiencing the issues with the application. Which of the following should the technician perform NEXT?

discussion.content: Guys the network technician has only been told that the user is having an issue with an application, we don't even know what application is giving him issues. So gathering the information like what application is he using, what problem is the user having is gathering information about the ticket.

speaks to the user who is experiencing the issues with the application -- speak to the users like "how are you", can I get your name then what is the cause of the problem. It is clear that you gathered information because you can not determine and plan an action without gathering information.

I assumed that speaker with the user was the same as gathering information, why else would I be talking with them? To ask about their weekend plans? Gotta love COMPTIA with their poorly-worded
 questions.

From the CompTIA objectives:
Identify the problem
- Gather information
- Duplicate the problem, if possible
- Question users
- Identify symptoms

Since we've already begun speaking to the user, we can safely assume we're already gathering information. Thus, the very next sub-step of step 1 is to, you guessed it, identify symptoms. This can come in the form of more questions to the user or by investigating other avenues, but you're already gathering information by questioning the user in any capacity, no matter how little.

Also, small rant, and this is a pretty good place to do it. What the hell even is a step like "gathering information" anyway? If you proceed to step 3 and test your working theory of a problem, the entire purpose of the step is to gather information on whether you have the right grasp of the problem or not. So when you do that are you in step 3? Step 1? Both?

Realistically speaking you're ALWAYS gathering information throughout the entire troubleshooting process, so the idea of having a blanket generic step such as "gather information" is about as useful as saying that step 1 is to exist, because you can't solve problems if you don't exist! Thanks CompTIA, any more wise words of wisdom?

Anyway, end rant.
I hate these kinds of questions. SPEAKS TO THE USER means you ARE GATHERING INFORMATION.
Simply speaking to a user doesnt mean you have gathered ALL information.
I agree with you since he has already informed about the issue.

comments.content: I don't think CompTIA release their questions to the public. The answers can be obtain just the the questions.
CompTia doesn't release the answer keys. The answers on these dump sites are just as easily wrong.
Agreed. I hate questions like this.

Speaking with a client is not gathering information, gathering information would be researching the issues using google, bing, etc.
Speaking with a user is not gathering information, it's just that- speaking with the user. Half the time users wont tell you everything that happened because of fear of repercussion.

discussion.content: "A network technician receives a trouble ticket and speaks to the user who is experiencing the issues with the application. Which of the following should the technician perform NEXT?"... The tech is ALREADY gathering information. The question doesn't say continue performing... It says "perform NEXT!"
